raw_text:
Safin cool on Wimbledon
 
 Newly-crowned Australian Open champion Marat Safin has ruled out any chance of winning Wimbledon in the future.
 
 After losing in round one last year, Safin said he had "given up" on Wimbledon and winning his second Grand Slam title has not changed his mind. "I'll play, but with no expectations. I feel like I can't waste my time, my energy on that surface," he said. "Some people, they cannot play on clay. Some people, they cannot play on a hard court. Me, I can't play on grass." However, Safin is hopeful that winning the Australian Open will give him the belief he needs to win more Grand Slam titles. "It's a relief for me. Two grand slams, it's already something. But with this one I worked really hard for it," he said. "Basically, I would love to win a couple more. I think I have a chance if I continue this way.
 
 "If (coach) Peter Lundgren will stick around with me and wants to work with me for a bit longer, I think I can make it." The 25-year-old shocked Pete Sampras in the 2000 US Open final to win his first major title but then lost in two Australian Open finals. Safin admitted he had begun to doubt whether he would win another Grand Slam. "I didn't expect that (to win the 2000 US Open) - it was against Sampras, I wasn't the favourite so I had no pressure whatsoever," he said. "After the first final that I didn't win against Thomas Johansson (in 2002), I couldn't see myself winning the Grand Slams anymore. "I was once in the semi-finals of the French Open, but I didn't believe I can win it. "I just couldn't handle the pressure. You need to believe in yourself, and I didn't."
 
 And after losing the first set 6-1 to Lleyton Hewitt in Sunday's final, Safin said he began to doubt himself again. "I am 25. I'm playing against Hewitt. At least you have to have the opportunity to win it, at least have a chance," he said. "It's like you go there and you lose first set 6-1, then you start to think: 'This is not my day. The way I'm playing is ridiculous.' "But then you start to really be a little bit more selfish and try to find a way out of there. "And I found it. I was like really much I was much happier than in 2000, that's for sure, because I get over it."
llama3.2:1b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon due to the surface being too difficult for him on clay and hard courts. He is hopeful that winning the Australian Open will boost his confidence and potentially lead to more Grand Slam titles. Safin had a mixed record at major finals, including losing in two consecutive Australian Open finals, but won his first US Open title in 2000.
llama3.2:3b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon, saying he can't play on grass after losing in the first round last year. However, winning his Australian Open title gave him hope to win more Grand Slam titles, which he had previously doubted after two Australian Open losses.
gemma2:2b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon in the future, believing he cannot play well on grass. He won the Australian Open and feels this victory will give him more confidence to win more Grand Slam titles.  He hopes to continue working with his coach, Peter Lundgren. Despite a challenging loss in the first round of Wimbledon last year, Safin acknowledges that winning the US Open title was unexpected, leaving him unsure about achieving further Grand Slams before.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Safin, 25, has given up on Wimbledon after losing the Australian Open semifinals in 2019 and won only one Grand Slam title. He now hopes to win more titles and believe he can make another Grand Slam appearance next year, with coach Peter Lundgren's support.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon again after losing last year due to grass court issues. He hopes the Australian Open win will give him confidence for future Grand Slam titles and is optimistic about continuing his rise in the ATP rankings with improved performances.
qwen2.5:3b: Marat Safin, a newly-crowned Australian Open champion, has ruled out any chance of winning Wimbledon in the future after his disappointing performance there last year. He believes he cannot perform well on grass courts and feels wasted playing on this surface. However, Safin remains hopeful that winning the Australian Open will boost his confidence for potential more Grand Slam victories if Peter Lundgren continues to work with him. Reflecting on past failures, including losing two consecutive finals at the Australian Open in 2002 and 2004, he now feels more comfortable about his chances of success. After a tough loss against Lleyton Hewitt in this year's Wimbledon final, Safin acknowledged doubting himself but managed to recover and perform better this time around.
opencoder:1.5b: Safin cool on Wimbledon is a summary of the text. He has given up on Wimbledon and may not win more Grand Slam titles. After losing in the Australian Open, he is hopeful he will continue to give himself the belief he needs to win more titles.

Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon in the future but remains hopeful about securing more Grand Slam titles. He acknowledged his "giveup" stance after losing the Australian Open and hinted at potential re-emergence of success with the Australian Open win. Safin reflects on past successes, including the 2000 US Open victory over Pete Sampras and his early doubts regarding future wins. He also mentions overcoming doubt after losing the first set 6-1 to Lleyton Hewitt in his last match.
tinyllama:1.1b: As Marat Safin has said, he is not willing to waste his time and energy playing on the prestigious Australian Open grass surface after losing both his Grand Slam finals. However, despite the lack of expectation, the Russian star has expressed hope that he will continue to win more slams in the future. With a focus on improving his performances and work with coach Peter Lundgren, Safin believes that he can make it at least to one Australian Open final within his next two years. In conclusion, despite having lost both Grand Slam finals, Marat Safin's newfound belief has allowed him to have the mindset to win more Slams in the future.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Marat Safin has ruled out winning Wimbledon in the future, opting instead to focus on his achievements in Grand Slam titles. However, he still holds strong beliefs about his ability to win another major championship. Despite facing significant challenges during his career, Safin remains hopeful that he will achieve his goal of winning a second Grand Slam title.

He admitted to doubting himself, but found a way out and is happier than in 2000.
